prompt.p: Reed–Sternberg cells are B lymphocytes that originate in the lymph node germinal centre but have lost the ability to produce antibodies.
In which of the following conditions are Reed–Sternberg cells seen?

modalFeedback.p: Option B (Hodgkin's lymphoma) is Correct. The cause of Hodgkin's disease is unknown, but Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection may play a role. The annual incidence is two or three per 100,000 with two incidence peaks: one in young adults, and the second in older individuals. Reed–Sternberg cells are characteristically seen when lymph nodes are biopsied. These cells are B lymphocytes that originate in the lymph node germinal centre but have lost the ability to produce antibodies.
Option A (Multiple myeloma) is Incorrect. Reed–Sternberg cells are typically seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Option C (CML) is Incorrect. Reed–Sternberg cells are typically seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Option D (ALL) is Incorrect. Reed–Sternberg cells are typically seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Option E (Plasmacytoma) is Incorrect. Reed–Sternberg cells are typically seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma.
